dt: {bc}lying at full length or spread out upon the ground {bc}{sx|prostrate||}

dt.t: The soldiers were lying {wi}flat{/wi} on the ground.
Push the chairs {wi}flat{/wi} against the wall.

dt: {bc}being or characterized by a horizontal line or tracing without peaks or depressions
{bc}having a relatively smooth or even surface
{bc}arranged or laid out so as to be level or even
{bc}having the major surfaces essentially parallel and distinctly greater than the minor surfaces
{bc}having no fraction either lacking or in excess {bc}{sx|exact||}

dt.t: He spoke in a {wi}flat{/wi}, tired voice.

dt: {bc}characterized by no significant rise or decline from one period to another

dt.t: made a {wi}flat{/wi} pass that was intercepted

dt: {bc}made so as to give little or no spin to the ball

dt.t: figures standing out against a background of {wi}flat{/wi} wash

dt: {bc}having little or no illusion of depth
{bc}of, relating to, or used in competition on the flat
{bc}having a mass such that expansion halts only after infinite time and collapse never occurs

pt: {sc}level{/sc} {sc}flat{/sc} {sc}plane{/sc} {sc}even{/sc} {sc}smooth{/sc} mean having a surface without bends, curves, or irregularities. {sc}level{/sc} applies to a horizontal surface that lies on a line parallel with the horizon.
{sc}flat{/sc} applies to a surface devoid of noticeable curvatures, prominences, or depressions.
{sc}plane{/sc} applies to any real or imaginary flat surface in which a straight line between any two points on it lies wholly within that surface.
{sc}even{/sc} applies to a surface that is noticeably flat or level or to a line that is observably straight.

pt.t: trim the hedge so it is {it}even{/it}

pt: {sc}smooth{/sc} applies especially to a polished surface free of irregularities.

{sc}insipid{/sc} {sc}vapid{/sc} {sc}flat{/sc} {sc}jejune{/sc} {sc}banal{/sc} {sc}inane{/sc} mean devoid of qualities that make for spirit and character. {sc}insipid{/sc} implies a lack of sufficient taste or savor to please or interest.

pt.t: an {it}insipid{/it} romance with platitudes on every page

pt: {sc}vapid{/sc} suggests a lack of liveliness, force, or spirit.

pt.t: an exciting story given a {it}vapid{/it} treatment

pt: {sc}flat{/sc} applies to things that have lost their sparkle or zest.

pt.t: although well-regarded in its day, the novel now seems {it}flat{/it}

pt: {sc}jejune{/sc} suggests a lack of rewarding or satisfying substance.
{sc}banal{/sc} stresses the complete absence of freshness, novelty, or immediacy.
{sc}inane{/sc} implies a lack of any significant or convincing quality.

et: Middle English, from Old Norse {it}flatr{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}flaz{/it} flat, and probably to Greek {it}platys{/it} broad {ma}{mat|place|}{/ma}
shortdef: lying at full length or spread out upon the ground : prostrate
resting with a surface against something
